Package corc.structure

Interface CardProperty<P extends CardProperty>

  • Type Parameters:
    P - the object implementing this. Used to reference the subclass for the Comparable interface.
    All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<P>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    IFace<F>, ISuit<S>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Face, Suit
    public interface CardProperty<P extends CardProperty>
extends java.lang.Comparable<P>
    Any attribute of an ICard object should be a subclass of this. This interface allows for consistency when attempting to read an attribute of a Card.

    A CardProperty SHOULD be immutable.

    Two fundamentally different instances of a CardProperty SHOULD NOT return the same results for both getName() and getValue(). At least one of those methods SHOULD return a different value.

    Examples: In Mahjong, all cards (tiles) in the "Dots" sub-category would likely all return "Dots" from getName(). However, there are nine different possible amounts of dots on each card. So, getValue() would return different amounts based on the number of dots on the card. And a card with five dots will have the same return values as another card with five dots.

    In a standard 52 card deck, when looking at the face properties of a "Five of Spades" and a "Five of Hearts". The face properties can return the same values for both getName() and getValue(). Since the faces by themselves are fundamentally the same. This rule is difficult to break in general (given the need for cards in a game to be distinguishable from the other cards in the same game).

    A clear example is a card in a standard 52 card deck, has a suit and a face. Suit and face would each be a separate CardProperty contained by a Card object.

    Another example would be in Mahjong, cards (tiles) belong to a category, and each category has sub-categories. In this example, a subclass of CardProperty, may contain another, different subclass of CardProperty. So in "Old Hong Kong Mahjong", a Card object might have an attribute "category". The category.getName() method would return one of: Simples, Honors, or Bonus. category would also most likely contain a sub-category. So Simples would contain an attribute (that is a subclass of CardProperty) of Dots, Bamboo, or Characters.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      java.lang.String getName()
      This method is used to get the common name for this CardProperty.
      int getValue()
      This method gets the value of this CardProperty.

      • Methods inherited from interface java.lang.Comparable

        compareTo

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
        This method is used to get the common name for this CardProperty.

        SHOULD be a unique common name of this CardProperty.

        For example: If the property is the face of the card in a standard 52 card deck, then any card with 'Five' as the face SHOULD return the same string. Since the property is only concerned about the face (any two cards with a face of "Five" are fundamentally the same, even though they might have different suits). While any other card, such as a 'Six' SHOULD return something different as its common name.

        Returns:
        The common name of this property.

      • getValue

        int getValue()
        This method gets the value of this CardProperty.

        SHOULD be unique to the common name of this CardProperty.

        For example: If the property is the face of the card in a standard 52 card deck, then any card with 'Five' as the face, SHOULD return the same value. While any other card, such as a 'Six' SHOULD return a different value.

        The main purpose of this method is to be used in the implementation of the Comparable interface. However, this method CAN be used for other purposes.

        This method SHOULD be used to distinguish between unique types of a common name for this CardProperty.

        Returns:
        The integer value of this property.
